last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>14992196
It's 75% there because the odds you're looking at is the chances of getting at least one heads out of two flips. It will always be 50% if you're looking at one flip. Turns out probabilities change when you change what you're treating as a success.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>14992296
Can you explain more?

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>14992302
If you're about to flip a coin, the odds of it being heads or tails is the same regardless of past flips. This is because we are only looking at the odds and outcome of one specific flip. However, the example in the OP image is not looking at a single flip. It is looking at multiple flips, specifically two. Each of the specific outcomes (HH, HT, TH, TT) individually have 25% probability of occurring. We are deciding that "at least one coin lands on heads" is a success in this case, and three out of four of those specific outcomes are successful in that regard. Therefore the odds of at least one heads in two flips becomes 75%.
At least one coin getting heads in x flips will become more likely as the size of x increases. It starts at 50% (because we're only looking at a single flip), it continues to 75% (as explained above), then it goes to 87.5%. A way to make this intuitive is to look at it backwards. The only way that our condition does not get satisfied is if every single coin flip results in tails. The more coin flips, the less likely it becomes for every single one to be tails.

Now hear me out on this before you just dismiss me and accuse me of being a tranny (which I am not, IWABAM).

If Gender was determined by having XX or XY chromosomes, that would mean that intersex people (like Klinefelters *men*, XXY) would be neither male nor female, but when we observe the various chromosomal variations that can cause intersexuality, we see that those intersex people with the Y-chromosome are men, and those lacking it are women.

So, is maleness just the presence of the Y-.chromosome and femaleness just the absence of it? Well it turns out, in even rarer cases, you can males without the Y-chromosome and females with the Y-chromosome, and this is typically explained by a chromosomal mutation in which a part of the Y-chromosome (more specifically, the SRY-gene) is transferred to another chromosome (explaining men without Y) or absent in the Y chromosome (explaining women with the Y), this would therefore mean that maleness is the presence of the SRY-gene, and femaleness the lack of said gene.

But since genes can be expressed to different extents, wouldn't this mean that gender is not a binary between men and women, but a spectrum between the lack of SRY-expression and having a high amount of SRY-expression

tl;dr It's proteins, not chromosomes, and since different people have varying amounts of a given protein due to different gene expressions, it would follow that sex is a spectrum, not a binary

NASA's Artemis 1 rocket blasted off the Kennedy Space Center in the early hours of Wednesday, "lighting up the night sky and accelerating on a journey that will take an astronaut-less capsule around the moon and back," reports the New York Times

At around 1:47 a.m. Eastern time, the four engines on the rocket's core stage ignited, along with two skinnier side boosters. As the countdown hit zero, clamps holding the rocket down let go, and the vehicle slipped Earth's bonds. A few minutes later, the side boosters and then the giant core stage dropped away. The rocket's upper engine then ignited to carry the Orion spacecraft, where astronauts will sit during later missions, toward orbit. Less than the two hours after launch, the upper stage will fire one last time to send Orion on a path toward the moon. On Monday, Orion will pass within 60 miles of the moon's surface. After going around the moon for a couple of weeks, Orion will head back to Earth, splashing down on Dec. 11 in the Pacific Ocean, about 60 miles off the coast of California.

This flight is a crucial test for NASA's Artemis program that aims to put astronauts to moon for real.

I wouldn't particularly say people "live life at different speeds", I would say that biology is inherently intrinsic. It's a very organic process that is based on certain principles, which play out in a multitude of ways. Different metabolic factors, brain genetics, epigenetic factors ranging from conditions in the womb to education, sexual maturity, etc. There are so many aspects to developing as a biological being and as a human being, for some a lot of things happen "earlier" and some a lot "later.

One of the biggest failings of our modern society is how fundamentally people look at the progression of life in terms of maturing and life events. It's a one-size-fits-all approach that is incredibly destructive on a large scale. Humans experience different facets of life at different "speeds" and with different inclinations. They benefit most from an environment where their individual traits can develop and flourish at the speed that suits them best, for some that is "faster" and for some that is "slower", and for some never at all. Our biological processes are not set and by cramming everyone into the same cookie-cutter expectation of mental, physical, social, sexual, intellectual, scholastic, financial, etc. etc. development we are doing irreparable harm to countless individuals and society as a whole.

But to really address this, you need such a huge corpus of work that deals with evolutionary speeds, the mechanics of human circadian rhythms and things like clock genes, brain development, global vs local rates of sexual development in adolescents, physical development differences in men and women and in different cultures/environments, differences with other primates and other mammals, the list goes on.

And even if you do manage that, you are not really going to break any of those societal misconceptions.

>>14991842
It's because those adult features aren't very useful in miniature size, larva sized fly aint going to fly. Having what is essentially vestigial non functional eyes, wings, legs and what not is just a waste of energy until the insect has grown enough to actually make use of them in their intended purpose. Additionally insects can't "grow" thanks to their exoskeletons so it's easier to grow as a larva and then transform to the adult instead of progressively molt. So instead they birth these ridiculously efficient feeding machines which then transform into the full thing when they have enough bodymass.
Basically the insects that undergo full transformation survived better than the ones that molt as they grow like crabs. Insect lifecycle is fast enough that producing basically defenseless larva stages that eat and grow fast is enough to overcome predators by sheer chance.

There's no such thing as wave function collapse. Prior to the scientist observing the cat, the cat is in a superposition of |alive> + |dead>. After observation, the scientist becomes entangled with the cat and the scientist/cat system is, relative to the perspective of an outsider, in a superposition of |cat is alive>|scientist sees cat is alive> + |cat is dead>|scientist sees cat is dead>. Quantum descriptions are all relative to the perspective you're talking about. If that third perspective observed the scientist/cat system, then he would become entangled and the system would be in a superposition relative to a 4th party.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>14988001
Not really. Productivity is generally measured across whole industries or economy-wide. In a real production function, the marginal product of an hour of labor varies across the production schedule, and with the quantity of labor and capital inputs. The actual marginal revenue for a good varies with the cost of these inputs and demand/supply for the good, so these are always moving targets. The problem with all the two way graphs is that they try to hold things constant that aren't.

Firms produce where marginal revenue = marginal cost (where productivity would be a price ceiling) only in perfectly competitive markets, which don't actually exist, or in perfect unregulated monopolies with perfect production function and demand curve information, which also don't exist. This can hold true for oligopolies but only if they form a perfect cartel.

Monopolistic competition will frequently lead to production at levels where MC > MR and in the short term this can happen in perfect competition too before correction by suppliers leaving the market.

This is sort of a side the point, which is that productivity has risen significantly over the half century with very little impact on real wages.

The best explanation I've seen for this is capital substitution essentially blocking out increases in wages, and the huge increase in labor supply created by globalization through off shoring and much higher migration rates. Also the rapid development of capital in developing countries and the entry of women into the workforce in much larger numbers, which dramatically expanded the labor supply. Huge increases in supply + easier substitution made the demand for labor more elastic while also ramping up supply.

The theory is just wrong. It is based on a tautology, the total goods and services produced per person in an economy = higher per person income in an economy. It's the same thing.

Notably, there are third world-like countries with high per capita GDP

Hi.
Does anyone know good videocourse, lecture or maybe a book covering physiology and functions of human brain according with recent human knowledge? Found only trash so far.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
The Great Courses generally has quite good lectures. They have undergrad level surveys and upper level classes. Honestly, a few have been better than most real classes I've had.

They have The Neuroscience of Everyday, which is probably what you're looking for. Biology and Human Behavior might be a good follow-up, it focuses more on the endocrine system and body as a whole.

Then they have several upper level classes just on memory, just in emotions, just on sensory systems, etc.

A bunch are free with Audible, but the exact ones rotate every month. For a few bucks a month you can get the videos on Amazon or Wonderium. Wonderium has more of the math courses, which are great. They have linear algebra, discreet mathematics, intro to proofs, formal logic, etc.

The Mind Body Philosophy class is one of the very best. What philosophy should be. Brings in a lot of relevant neuroscience and explores their implications. I would definitely consider it as a follow up.

The one on human language acquisition is really good too.

You could get va BA worth done there too. They have intro biology, chemistry, and biochemistry and organic to fill in gaps

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>14983139
Introduction to Psychology by Gray and Bjorklund.

It takes an very very elementary approach and builds up knowledge of psychology and the functioning of the human brain by FIRST going into scientific methodology and theory construction and explaining evolutionary principles common in animals and humans.

You start out with an excellent basic interpretative framework, which they use to intuitively guide you through elementary elements of psychology and how they relate to how the brain is structured. From that they develop both broader topics as well as more in-depth analyses.

After you have that under your belt, you have all the tools to go look for yourself for what interests you about the human brain.

On the left side of the green line is a representation for overlaying the three panels in each row into one amalgam. white circles and black circles are drawn normally, but a little 'x' next to a black circle indicates that we know a white circle is hiding under it just from combining the images, and a highlighted star shows where a white circle must be hiding, but is never uncovered by a black circle in order for the white circles to fill every position (assumed rule for now, demonstrated later). a question mark shows where a white circle might appear in our answer.

originally, i assumed that these hidden white circles with star annotations should be there because it's a nice pattern for the puzzle, but you have a good point that there isn't much evidence for this besides the solution just being elegant. furthermore, we can't rule out F as a possible answer unless we assume that the two white dots in any given panel are adjacent, which is also a nice pattern that seems to be followed but up til now I didn't justify very well at all and simply assumed.

Upon a little additional inspection I noticed something new about the white circles. It was already clear that there were always at most two white circles per panel, and that in any given panel the missing white circle *could* be hiding behind an adjacent black circle. By adjacent I mean only horizontally or vertically so btw, not diagonally. but here's the new thing -- now moving to the diagram on the right side of the green line, here are ALL the white circles in each panel without any black circles obscuring them. in the bottom left panel i drew an X over the covered white circle in the answer and a ! to show one that must be visible. Not only would this be a way for the white circles to occupy every possible space in each row amalgam, which I'd assumed before, but they follow a nice pattern! Ill reply again.

last_replies.name: shmalculus
last_replies.com:
>>14986705
okay, here's the nice part. so we're now gonna operate with the idea in mind that every panel has exactly two white circles somewhere on it, but that the panels with only one white circle are hiding an additional one under an adjacent black circle. I claimed that this was the case earlier when I said that the white dots cover every position, but here's why it makes sense that they would.

now consider the blue diagonal line through the three panels from the bottom left to the top right. see how, starting from the bottom left, the white circles travel clockwise toward their next position in the panel diagonally above and to the right of it? Now, looking at the yellow lines, make a complete diagonal by shifting the top left panel over to the right so that the yellow line connects up properly. now if we start at the bottom-left-most yellow panel and move up diagonally and to the right, we observe the white circles doing a similar march to before, but now going counter clockwise!

the simplest rules we can infer are thus:
1. there are exactly two white circles present in every panel, though one of them may be covered up by a black circle
2. the two white circles are always adjacent
3. the white circles will move along these diagonals continuously by shifting clockwise or counterclockwise, depending on which diagonal they fall on.

this describes the behavior of the white circles without the hand-wavy justification that it just simplifies the puzzle to imagine that they do, and gives a solid reason for why the white circles are always adjacent and come only in pairs.

now let's look at the pink diagonal! looking at the top middle and left middle panels, we can see that in order to follow this rule there are only two configurations that work, moving clockwise or counter clockwise to get the new white circle positions. BUT, see how in the top two rows, the white circles occupy every possible position? use that to say the pink diagonal movement must be clockwise!

last_replies.name: shmalculus
last_replies.com:
>>14986705
so now we've used all 3 new rules about the white circles :)
1. we surmised that not only *might* there be white circles hiding under black circles, but that there are always exactly two white circles present!
2. then, using the patterns from the available panels, extrapolated that the two white circles are always adjacent!
3. finally, looking at the diagonals, that the white circles march in the same direction by one position along their respective diagonal.

if it's clearer, i'm now realizing that rule 3 can be also be thought of by thinking of the rows in a similar way. across a row, the white circles will move two positions either clockwise or counterclockwise from the leftmost panel to the rightmost panel.

now let's add back in our condition from earlier (which we observed in the top two rows) that
4. the white circles *must* cover every available position when amalgamating the row together.

if we follow that rule now, it directs us to decide that the pink diagonal motion is clockwise, or equivalently that the bottom row's motion is counterclockwise, but with the white circles moving two positions instead of just one.

with all that said, we can now much more confidently spot the white circle positions for the bottom right panel (the answer panel) as being what I drew in that panel in the diagram. In order to keep the rule for the black circles consistent, we draw one black circle in the middle left of the panel. now, we've ruled out option F because the white circles aren't adjacent (2), along with option C because the white circles dont show up in every position (4), along with every option besides A because it violates the white circle traversal rule (3). that leaves us with only one option, the natural one that we arrived at without process of elimination anyway! the answer must be A!

rigorously justifying these assumptions certainly transforms this puzzle quite a bit, I underestimated the extra work involved if you dont just assume stuff heh

last_replies.name: Anonymous

>>14987339
I get:
(8/√3)·(1/2)^n·sin(πn/3) - 4·(1/2)^n·cos(πn/3) + 4δ[n]
You should be doing partial fraction decomposition in terms of z^-1, not z. That should produce a constant term of 4 => 4δ[n] and terms matching #21 and #22 with ω0=π/3 => sin(ω0)=√3/2, cos(ω0)=1/2 in
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Z_transform#Table_of_common_Z-transform_pairs
Or you can factor the denominator using complex roots to get two terms matching #11 with complex a and complex scale factor; their sum will be real because the a's and scale factors are conjugates.

In the case of a quadratic denominator with complex roots:

A(1/z)^2 + B(1/z) + C

first factor it so that the constant coefficient is 1:

(A/C)(1/z)^2 + (B/C)(1/z) + 1

Matching coefficients against 1-2a·cos(ω0)·(1/z)+a^2·(1/z)^(2)

=> (A/C)=a^2 => a=√(A/C)

=> (B/C)=-2a·cos(ω0) => cos(ω0)=-(B/C)/2a

From there, you can match the numerator against cases 19-22 (and case 1, Z{δ[n]}=1).
